item.title: Mathmatical modeling for love story of Romeo and Juliet
Bubbles inside our cells
item.description: Phase separation in biological systems Phase separation is a common physical phenomenon. During the past decade, many researches have proved it takes part in cellular programs such as stress response, metabolisms and development. Personally, I would like to divide the phase separation processes in cell into two groups, liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) and liquid-to-solid phase separation. Although the formation of the both processes rely on the similar mechanism, the properties are quite different and can contribute to different biological programs.

item.title: About me
item.description: I’m a Biophysics PhD student at University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. My research interests include synthetic biology, biophysical complex systems, mathematical biology and developmental biology. Specifically, my works mainly focused on using synthetic systems and stochastic modeling to reconstitute cell asymmetry and differentiation. For me, lives are soft machines which are well-established. If we could reconstruct those systems with essential and minimal components, it means that we could create a new form of life.
